text: Jean-Louis Aubert (15 February 1731 in Paris – 10 November 1814 in Paris), called the Abbé Aubert, was a French dramatist, poet and journalist, son of the violinist and composer Jacques Aubert (1686-1753) and brother of Louis Aubert (painter). Aubert was educated at the Collège de Navarre and entered the order. In 1741, Aubert entered the editorial staff of the ', where he was literary critic. In 1752, he created the '. He opposed the encyclopedists. Aubert published ' in the Mercure de France and in 1756 '. Grimm found his fables "just good for children, not being allowed to be too difficult"; Voltaire on the contrary recommended them. 1761-1763 appeared the ', 1765 ' and '. A protégé of Vergennes, Aubert joined the Journal de Trévoux, replacing the abbé Mercier, which he renamed the '. In 1773, he was made chair of literature at the Collège Royal and replaced Marin as director of the Gazette de France in 1774.
